faq.description: Find answers to common questions about our i-signature platform and services.

q1.question: What is the i-signing tool?
q1.answer: Our i-signing tool is a secure digital solution that allows you to sign, send, and manage documents online, eliminating the need for printing, scanning, or mailing.

q2.question: Who can use the i-signing tool?
q2.answer: It‚Äôs designed for businesses of all sizes, freelancers, and individuals who need to legally sign or request signatures on documents.

q3.question: Do signers need an account to sign documents?
q3.answer: No. Recipients can sign documents without creating an account. They just receive a secure link to review and sign.

q4.question: Is the i-signing tool legally binding?
q4.answer: Yes. Our solution complies with major i-signature regulations, including eIDAS (EU), eSIGN Act (US), and UETA, making signed documents legally valid and enforceable.

q5.question: How secure are my documents?
q5.answer: All documents are encrypted during transfer and storage. We use SSL/TLS encryption and industry-standard security measures to protect your data.

q6.question: Can I track who signed my document and when?
q6.answer: Yes. Each document comes with a detailed audit trail, showing when it was opened, viewed, and signed.

q7.question: Is the tool GDPR-compliant?
q7.answer: Absolutely. We follow GDPR guidelines for data protection, storage, and consent handling.

q8.question: Are i-signatures accepted worldwide?
q8.answer: E-signatures are legally recognized in most countries. However, some specific documents (like wills, property deeds, or court filings) may still require wet-ink signatures.

q9.question: Can I customize my signature style?
q9.answer: Yes. You can draw your signature, upload an image, or choose from predefined styles.

q10.question: What file types are supported?
q10.answer: We support PDF, Word, Excel, and most common document formats.

q11.question: Can I sign on mobile devices?
q11.answer: Yes. Our tool is fully responsive and works on smartphones, tablets, and desktops.

q12.question: Can I request multiple signatures on one document?
q12.answer: Yes. You can assign signing roles, set signing order, and collect multiple signatures.

q13.question: Can I set reminders for unsigned documents?
q13.answer: Yes. Automatic reminders can be sent to recipients until they sign.

q14.question: Can I prevent document changes after signing?
q14.answer: Yes. Once signed, the document is locked to prevent further modifications.

q15.question: Is there a free trial?
q15.answer: Yes. We offer a free trial with limited features so you can test the tool before upgrading.

q16.question: Do you offer team or enterprise plans?
q16.answer: Yes. We have flexible plans for individuals, teams, and large organizations with additional features like bulk sending, branding, and integrations.

q17.question: Which payment methods do you accept?
q17.answer: We accept major credit/debit cards, PayPal, and invoice-based payments for enterprise customers.

header.title: Understanding Digital Signatures
header.subtitle: A comprehensive guide to electronic signatures and their legal framework under eIDAS

overview.title: What is a Digital Signature?
overview.p1: A digital signature is a specific form of electronic signature that uses advanced cryptographic methods to securely link a signer to a document. It provides the highest level of assurance regarding the authenticity of the signer and the integrity of the signed document.
overview.p2_suffix: an internationally recognized standard that ensures documents cannot be altered once signed and that the signer's identity can be reliably verified. This makes digital signatures particularly important for transactions requiring strong legal certainty.

comparison.title: Electronic vs Digital Signatures
comparison.p1_text: are a broad category of methods used to indicate a person's intent to sign a document in digital form. They are widely adopted because they are simple to use, quick to implement, and legally recognized under the EU eIDAS Regulation (No. 910/2014). Common use cases include employment contracts, purchase orders, invoices, and customer agreements.
comparison.p2_text: on the other hand, are a specific type of electronic signature that use advanced cryptographic technology to provide stronger security and authentication. They are particularly important in highly regulated industries and are explicitly defined under eIDAS.

types.title: Three Types Under eIDAS
types.description: Under the EU eIDAS Regulation, electronic signatures are categorized into three levels, from least to most stringent:

ses.title: Simple (SES)
ses.description: Basic forms of i-sign.eus, suitable for low-risk documents.

aes.title: Advanced (AES)
aes.description: Higher security, uniquely linked to the signer with verified identity.

qes.title: Qualified (QES)
qes.description: Most secure, legally equivalent to handwritten signatures.

tip.text: While digital signatures may appear complex at first, they become much clearer once the key elements are understood. Explore each tab above to learn when to use each type of signature.

ses.title: Simple Electronic Signature (SES)
ses.subtitle: For everyday transactions
ses.p1: A Simple Electronic Signature (SES) is the most basic type of electronic signature under the eIDAS Regulation. It does not require advanced methods of signer authentication or identity verification.

howItWorks.title: How It Works
howItWorks.p1: In practice, an SES may involve something as straightforward as:
howItWorks.li1: Entering a PIN or access code
howItWorks.li2: Clicking "I accept" or ticking a checkbox
howItWorks.li3: Providing a signature through an email-linked signing process

useCases.title: Common Use Cases
useCases.p1: This type of signature is often sufficient for low-risk, day-to-day transactions, such as:

warning.text: While SES offers speed and convenience, it provides the lowest level of assurance regarding the signer's identity and document integrity. For higher-risk or regulated transactions, stronger forms of signature such as Advanced (AES) or Qualified (QES) may be required.

ses.learnMoreLink: Learn more about standard i-sign.eu implementation ‚Üí

aes.title: Advanced Electronic Signature (AES)
aes.subtitle: For high-value transactions
aes.p1: An Advanced Electronic Signature (AES) offers a higher level of security than a Simple Electronic Signature. It requires additional authentication steps to ensure that the signer's identity is verified and that the signature is uniquely linked to them.

requirements.title: eIDAS Requirements
requirements.p1: To qualify as AES under eIDAS, the signature must meet the following criteria:
requirements.li1: It is uniquely linked to the signer
requirements.li2: It is capable of identifying the signer
requirements.li3: It is created using electronic signature creation data that the signer can maintain under their sole control
requirements.li4: It is linked to the signed data in such a way that any subsequent change to the data is detectable

item3.title: Digital Certificates
item3.description: Unique certificate generated for the transaction

item4.title: One-Time Passcode
item4.description: Unique OTP sent to verified device

benefits.title: Key Benefits
benefits.li2: A unique link between the signature and the signed document

example.title: Example Use Case
example.p1_prefix: High-value or sensitive business transactions, such as
example.p1_suffix: where the organization needs stronger assurance of the signer's identity and the document's integrity.

aes.learnMoreLink: Learn more about i-sign.eu verification methods ‚Üí

qes.title: Qualified Electronic Signature (QES)
qes.subtitle: For highly regulated transactions
qes.p1: A Qualified Electronic Signature (QES) is the most secure and trusted form of electronic signature defined under the EU eIDAS Regulation. It requires a face-to-face or equivalent identity verification process carried out by a Qualified Trust Service Provider (QTSP), either in the EU or the UK.

foundation.title: Technical Foundation
foundation.p1_suffix: and a qualified certificate issued by a recognized provider. This process ensures that:
foundation.li1: The signer's identity has been verified to the highest legal standard
foundation.li2: The signature is uniquely linked to the signer and the signed document
foundation.li3: A complete and tamper-proof audit trail is created

equivalence.title: Legal Equivalence
equivalence.p1_prefix: Because of these assurances, a QES is considered the
equivalence.p1_strong: legal equivalent of a handwritten signature
equivalence.p2: In fact, legal experts often argue that a QES can be more reliable than a traditional signature witnessed in an unsupervised setting, since the digital process ensures stronger identity verification and document integrity.

useCases.title: Common Use Cases
useCases.p1: QES is generally required for highly regulated or sensitive transactions, such as:

q1.title: How does a Qualified Electronic Signature (QES) work with i-sign.eu?
q1.p1: A QES requires strong identity authentication before a digital certificate can be issued. It provides the highest level of trust through face-to-face, or equivalent, ID verification. During the signing process, customers are asked to electronically confirm their identity. Once verified, a digital certificate proving their identity is automatically attached to the signature behind the scenes.
q1.p2: i-sign.eu offers multiple options for QES with integrated ID verification. Digital certificates are issued by recognized Certificate Authorities (Trust Service Providers), and i-sign.eu accepts qualified certificates issued by providers listed on the official EU Trust List.

q2.title: How does an Advanced Electronic Signature (AES) work with i-sign.eu?
q2.p1: An AES with i-sign.eu involves additional steps to authenticate the signer. This may include presenting a valid government-issued document to confirm identity, combined with a one-time access code after the signing process. AES signatures require a PKI-based digital certificate, which is generated and attached to the document as part of the transaction.
q2.p2: i-sign.eu provides flexible ID verification options to meet both Advanced and Qualified levels of electronic signatures under eIDAS.

q3.title: How does a Simple Electronic Signature (SES) work with i-sign.eu?
q3.p1: SES is the most commonly used and broadly accepted type of i-sign.eu worldwide. With i-sign.eu, SES can replace handwritten signatures in most low-risk cases. It is particularly suitable for:
q3.p2: SES is quick, efficient, and requires few steps. However, if stronger signer authentication is needed, an AES or QES may be required instead.
